title: Who decides if a book gets published? - Quora

response.answer_text: The publisher. For self-publishing, that’s the author. For vanity publishing (where the author pays the publisher — please don’t do this), it’s mostly the author, but the publisher may refuse a book that’s defamatory, libelous, plagiarized, or just so awful they don’t want their name on it. Ordinarily, though, they’ll take just about anything so long as they’re paid. Some lie and claim to be selective in what they’ll accept; others are up front about it. For traditional publishing, the person at the publishing company who reads submissions and chooses what should be published is called an acquiring editor. Some acquiring editors are given free rein to buy and publish anything they want; others submit their choices to a publishing committee, where the marketing or legal departments may overrule them and refuse to publish a book the editor wanted. At small presses, the acquiring editor and the publisher are often the same person. Whatever the situation, the final say goes to the publisher, whether that’s an individual or a corporation — which is why he, she, or it is called “the publisher”.

The publisher. There are no appeals. The verdict of the publisher is final. Of course, there are many publishers, at many levels, and the rule of law that judges the merits of a book is subjectively interpreted. Case closed. Or opened, depending.
